prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Juste output your new text, nothing else.  Here is the text: One objection to the views of those who, like Mr. Gulick, believe isolation itself to be a cause of modification of species deserves attention, namely, the entire absence of change where, if this were a _vera causa_, we should expect to find it. In Ireland we have an excellent test case, for we know that it has been separated from Britain since the end of the glacial epoch, certainly many thousand years. Yet hardly one of its mammals, reptiles, or land molluscs has undergone the slightest change, even although there is certainly a distinct difference in the environment both inorganic and organic. That changes have not occurred through natural selection, is perhaps due to the less severe struggle for existence owing to the smaller number of competing species; but, if isolation itself were an efficient cause, acting continuously and c.u.mulatively, it is incredible that a decided change should not have been produced in thousands of years. That no such change has occurred in this, and many other cases of isolation, seems to prove that it is not in itself a cause of modification.
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Juste output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
stories:
The argument that physical separation can lead to biological differences in species, as proposed by proponents such as Mr. Gulick, has a notable exception that merits consideration. This exception lies in the total lack of modification found in instances where one would expect such changes to have occurred. Ireland, for instance, serves as a compelling example, having been isolated from Britain since the end of the last ice age. Despite the clearly distinct environmental differences, both in terms of its geology and the life forms that inhabit it, there has been a remarkable absence of modification in the majority of its mammals, reptiles, and land mollusks.

The idea that these species have remained unchanged due to a less intense struggle for survival, as a result of fewer competing species, is an interesting proposition. However, if isolation itself were a significant and cumulative cause of modification, as asserted, it is incredibly unlikely that we would not observe some level of change in these isolated populations over the course of thousands of years.

The fact that such changes have not manifested in this and many other cases of isolation suggests that there might be other factors at play that contribute to the modification of species, or that isolation itself may not be as influential a cause as some theorists suggest.

The hypothesis that geographical isolation can result in distinct biological characteristics among species, as advocated by certain scientists including Mr. Gulick, has an notable exemption worth contemplating. This exception manifests in the form of no genetic variation in locations where one would anticipate such developments. For instance, Iceland, which has been isolated from Europe since the end of the last ice age, serves as a striking example. Despite the obvious differences in its environment, such as the geological composition and the life forms that inhabit it, there is a noticeable absence of genetic diversity in the majority of its mammals, reptiles, and land invertebrates.

One plausible explanation is that the species have remained genetically unaltered due to a less intense evolutionary pressure, resulting from a reduced number of competing species. Nevertheless, if isolation itself were a substantial and compounding factor for genetic modification, as some researchers propose, it is highly improbable that we would not detect any genetic changes in these isolated populations over the course of thousands of years.

The reality that such alterations have not emerged in this instance, as well as in numerous other cases of isolation, suggests that there could be additional factors influencing the genetic modification of species. Alternatively, isolation might not be as significant a cause as some scientists suggest. Further investigation is needed to determine the complex interplay between these factors and to fully understand the mechanisms of evolution.
